item.title: Britain’s Big Squeeze: In Britain, Even Children Are Feeling the Effects of Austerity
item.media:description: Waiting for lunch at Morecambe Bay Primary School in Morecambe, England. About a third of the school’s 350 students would not have breakfast unless the school provided it, one teacher said.
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times
item.description: Changes to welfare benefits and funding cuts are driving the working poor into crisis — and reversing a long-term decline in the childhood poverty rate.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Trump Accuses China of Interfering in Midterm Elections
item.media:description: President Trump told the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that the Chinese “do not want me or us to win, because I am the first president to ever challenge China on trade.”
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: The president offered no evidence of Chinese meddling in the November vote, but he has previously accused China of aiming tariffs at American states that support him.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Hundreds of Cases a Day and a Flair for Drama: India’s Crusading Supreme Court
item.media:description: Unlike the United States Supreme Court, which agrees to hear only about 70 cases a year, the various panels of the Indian Supreme Court hear up to 700 legal matters a day.
item.description: As the country’s politics have veered to the right and become increasingly divisive, the justices have often acted as a progressive counterweight.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN, HARI KUMAR and KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: U.N. General Assembly Updates: Israelis and Palestinians to Address Meeting
item.media:description: China’s foreign affairs minister, Wang Yi, right, at the Security Council briefing.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: World leaders gathered in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, after two days dominated by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Turkey’s Erdogan Changes His Tune, Seeking Support and Cooperation in Germany
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Hamburg, Germany, last year.
item.description: A state visit is aimed at normalizing relations with a NATO partner, but it also underscores that Europe has to deal with a budding dictator on its border.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Don’t You Hate When a Seal Slaps You in the Face With an Octopus?
item.description: Kyle Mulinder does. As he kayaked in New Zealand, the fateful moment was captured on video.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Jacinda Ardern’s Progressive Politics Made Her a Global Sensation. But Do They Work at Home?
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand at the United Nations this week.
item.description: The New Zealand prime minister’s values, charisma and status as a new mother have made her a superstar. But critics say there is much more to leadership.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE GRAHAM-McLAY

item.title: Neighbors Refer Venezuela to Criminal Court in ‘Historic’ Rebuke
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro, center, in Caracas this week. The crisis in Venezuela “demands collective action,” the president of Peru said.
item.description: Argentina, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Paraguay and Peru have urged the International Criminal Court to investigate abuses in Venezuela. Here’s what that means.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO and MARLISE SIMONS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Russian Officer Is Named as Suspect in Salisbury Poisoning
item.media:description: A new report says that “Ruslan Boshirov,” one of the suspects in the poisoning of a former Russian spy, is really Col. Anatoly V. Chepiga, an officer in Russia’s military intelligence service.
item.description: A group of investigative journalists from Britain and Russia traced the identity of a suspect whose passport name was assumed to be an alias.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: China Rejects Trump’s Charges of Meddling in U.S. Elections
item.media:description: President Trump told the United Nations Security Council on Wednesday that the Chinese “do not want me or us to win.”
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Trump called a paid China Daily insert in an Iowa newspaper “propaganda.” Chinese officials said the advertising was both lawful and commonplace.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: France’s New Law Against Sexist Catcalls Gets Its First Conviction
item.media:description: A fresco commissioned to reassure female commuters in Lyon, France. The verbal harassment case occured on a bus in the suburbs of Paris.
item.description: A man was fined for lewd, insulting comments to a woman aboard a bus. He was also jailed, for slapping her behind and hitting the bus driver.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Japan’s Embrace of Bilateral Trade Talks With U.S. Spares It From Tariffs
item.media:description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan with President Trump in New York on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Japan may have given President Trump a chance to declare victory, but in the short term it has escaped damaging tariffs on its auto industry.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: In KFC’s China Ads, Nuggets Are Served With Patriotism
item.description: The fast food chain’s campaign celebrates the country’s four-decade rise from rural poverty to the world’s second-largest economy.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY MAY and ZOE MOU

item.title: Letter 74: Sounding Out The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand at the United Nations this week.
item.description: This week’s Australia Letter brings the world to your ears, exploring how journalism is bending toward creativity.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: 383,000: Estimated Death Toll in South Sudan’s War
item.media:description: Displaced South Sudanese in Bentiu, South Sudan, last year.
item.description: The new report offers the first comprehensive tally of the scale of devastation in a largely forgotten war.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

item.title: North Korea Nuclear Deal Could Take ‘Years,’ Trump Suggests
item.media:description: President Trump says a letter from North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, demonstrates “his feelings for wanting to get this done.”
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Speaking on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly session, he reversed the position he took a year ago that the North had to disarm rapidly.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Seeing Ally Against Muslims, Some German Jews Embrace Far Right, to Dismay of Others
item.media:description: Alexander Gauland, the co-leader of the Alternative for Germany party, preparing a speech in Parliament this month.
item.description: Jewish members of the Alternative for Germany party approve of its hostility to Muslims. But the AfD is also a home to Holocaust apologists.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Brett Kavanaugh, U.N., Interest Rates: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB, JEAN RUTTER and MARCUS PAYADUE

item.title: Jeremy Corbyn, in Labour Speech, Vows to Fight Capitalist ‘Greed’
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, speaking at a Labour Party conference in Liverpool on Wednesday, said it would be a “national disaster” if Britain quit the European Union without a deal.
item.description: Mr. Corbyn, speaking at a party conference, outlined a “radical plan to rebuild and transform” Britain. The party remains split on Brexit.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: New Zealand Premier Takes Baby to the U.N.
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand took her 3-month-old daughter along with her to the United Nations General Assembly.

item.title: Trump Accuses China of Interfering in Midterms
item.description: Without offering proof, President Trump, as chairman of the United Nations Security Council meeting, assailed the Chinese for election meddling. He also took credit for stemming violence in Syria and said his ties with North Korea were strengthening.

item.title: Trump Vows to Release Mideast Peace Plan Within 4 Months
item.description: Mr. Trump said he favored a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. His administration has been working on a peace plan for nearly two years.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: A Beluga Whale Surfaces in the Thames, and Britain Marvels
item.description: It is said to be the most southerly sighting of the Arctic species in British waters. Conservationists hope the animal will swim back to the ocean.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Our Investigative Reporters Explain the Trump-Russia Story
item.media:description: President Trump and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Helsinki, Finland, in July.
item.description: Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane answer readers’ questions on Russian interference in the 2016 election, the Mueller investigation and their reporting process.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: She Was Called a Hero for Helping Fellow Refugees. Doing So Got Her Arrested.

media:description.p: Sarah Mardini, left, and her sister, Yusra, receiving awards in Germany in 2016. They fled Syria the year before, using their swimming skills to guide an overloaded dinghy to safety.

item.description: Sarah Mardini, credited with helping to rescue people on a sinking boat, and four others working for a Greek aid group face charges that could put them in prison for decades.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: Pope Francis Asks Chinese Catholics to Trust His Deal With Government
item.media:description: Pope Francis in the Vatican on Wednesday. In a letter, he appealed to Chinese Catholics to “place your trust ever more firmly in the Lord of history and in the church’s discernment of his will.”
item.description: Facing criticism that he had conceded too much, the pope said he appreciated the sacrifices of his flock, and he urged state and church to cooperate.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Airstrikes Are Killing More Civilians in Afghanistan, U.N. Warns
item.media:description: At least 24 civilians were killed in airstrikes in Afghanistan since Saturday.
item.description: At least 24 Afghan civilians have been killed in recent days in three separate attacks by Afghan or coalition planes.
item.dc:creator: FAHIM ABED and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: U.N. General Assembly: Trump Leads Security Council Meeting
item.media:description: China’s foreign affairs minister, Wang Yi, right, at the Security Council briefing.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Returning to the United Nations on Wednesday, President Trump led a meeting on the issue of nonproliferation at the Security Council.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Germany Dispatch: Face Paint, Balloons and ‘White Power’: German Neo-Nazis Put on a Pretty Face
item.media:description: The annual Eichsfeld Day festival shows the inroads being made by right-wing groups in Germany.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Clashes in the German city of Chemnitz drew global attention. But a festival in tiny Leinefelde reflects the quieter inroads being made by the far right.
item.dc:creator: JOHN ELIGON

item.title: Swedish Skit Mocks Chinese Tourists, Drawing Backlash in China
item.media:description: After a satirical Swedish show, “Svenska Nyheter,” aired a skit about tourists from China, the Chinese Embassy urged the program to engage in “profound reflection” and apologize.
item.description: Chinese officials demanded an apology over a Swedish satirical program’s skit about Chinese tourists, which the network says was meant to highlight racism.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: A Homage to Chinese Communism Is Destroyed in Taiwan
item.media:description: Wei Ming-jen, a Taiwan native hired to build an addition to the century-old Biyung Temple, fixing a flagpole in April. Part of the temple was demolished Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.description: A man’s decision to turn part of a Buddhist temple into a shrine to China’s Communist Party stirred outrage in Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN and KAROLINE KAN

item.title: India’s Top Court Limits Sweep of Biometric ID Program
item.description: The Supreme Court said the Aadhaar fingerprint ID system is legal, but restricted it to government benefits and banned companies from using it.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Mexican Authorities Disarm Acapulco Police Amid Corruption Inquiry
item.media:description: Military personnel and federal police officers in Acapulco, Mexico, on Tuesday. Two Acapulco police commanders have been arrested on homicide charges and the rest of the force is facing investigation.
item.description: The federal and state police, backed by the army, took over security in the resort city, where the local force is suspected to have been infiltrated by organized crime.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: A Marine’s Son Takes On U.S. Military Bases in Okinawa
item.media:description: Denny Tamaki, center, a candidate for governor of Okinawa, wants an American military base moved from the island.
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.description: “My father is American and my mother is Okinawan,” Denny Tamaki tells voters on the Japanese islands where he is running for governor.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Merkel’s Party Ousts Chancellor’s Close Ally From Top Post
item.media:description: Volker Kauder, right, with Chancellor Angela Merkel prior to a joint meeting of the Christian Democratic Union and Christian Social Union parties’ parliamentary bloc in Berlin on Tuesday.
item.description: The surprise defeat dealt a blow to the German leader’s authority in her own ranks.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Deliberate or Not, Trump’s Speech Draws Laughter at the U.N.
item.description: President Trump’s unscripted moment, when his bragging elicited laughter at the General Assembly, became the defining moment of his speech.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Bolton Warns of ‘Terrible Consequences’ for Those Doing Business with Iran
item.media:description: John R. Bolton, the national security adviser, speaking in New York on Tuesday.
item.description: Senior members of the Trump administration promised harsh penalties for European governments and companies that defy Iran sanctions.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)

item.title: Fact Check of the Day: Fact-Checking Trump’s Speech to the United Nations
item.description: Addressing the world body’s annual General Assembly meeting on Tuesday, President Trump made inaccurate claims about his own record, the Islamic State, the war in Yemen, reactions to the Iran nuclear deal and the trade deficit.
item.dc:creator: LINDA QIU
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Bill Cosby, Brett Kavanaugh, U.N.: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB, JEAN RUTTER and HIROKO MASUIKE

item.title: Germany’s Bishops Apologize for Sex Abuse and Pledge to Pursue Justice
item.media:description: Cardinal Reinhard Marx, left, and Bishop Stephan Ackermann at a news conference Tuesday presenting the findings of a study into sexual abuse.
item.description: The Roman Catholic Bishops’ Conference said the church had failed to take the abuse of children at the hands of clergy members seriously enough.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Swiss Denied Roman Abramovich Residency Over Suspected Criminality
item.media:description: The Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich, center, at court in Fribourg, Switzerland, in May.
item.description: A media group published details from a Swiss police letter recommending that the Russian oligarch not be allowed to settle in an Alpine village.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: China Rejects U.S. Warship’s Visit to Hong Kong as Tensions Rise
item.media:description: The USS Wasp, with a Marine Corps MV-22 Osprey aircraft flying nearby, off Okinawa in March.
item.description: The cancellation, along with recalling a senior admiral who was in the United States for a conference, came in response to sanctions imposed by the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Angola Holds Ex-Ruler’s Son on Fraud Charge
item.media:description: The entrance to a prison in Luanda where José Filomeno dos Santos was being held on Tuesday.
item.description: The government moved against José Filomeno dos Santos, son of José Eduardo dos Santos and former head of Angola’s sovereign wealth fund.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Greece’s Biggest Migrant Camp Is a Mental Health Crisis, Aid Groups Say
item.media:description: Refugees and migrants at the Moria refugee camp in Lesbos, Greece, last month. It has 8,500 residents but the capacity for only 3,100, an aid group’s report said.
item.description: Violence, suicide attempts and mental trauma are common in the Moria camp and could boil over, the groups say, even as other countries harden their stands on migrants.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: What Happens to a Hub of Renaissance Florence When the Friars Move Out?
item.media:description: The facade of the church of San Marco in Florence, Italy. The convent is attached.
item.description: The San Marco convent, central to the legacies of Fra Angelico and Savonarola, is closing, a victim of the Roman Catholic Church’s dwindling clergy ranks.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.category: Ministry of Cultural Heritage and Tourism (Italy)

item.title: Trump Speech at U.N.: Scorn for Iran, Praise for Kim
item.media:description: President Trump addressing the 73rd Session of the United Nations General Assembly on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: The president, at the General Assembly, doubled down on his “America First” foreign policy. He did have a few kind words for Kim Jong-un of North Korea.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: What Is the United Nations? Explaining Its Purpose, Power and Problems
item.media:description: Representatives of 50 countries at the United Nations Conference on International Organization, in San Francisco in 1945.
item.description: A look at the global organization as representatives of the 193 member countries gather for the 73rd annual session of the General Assembly.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Sweden’s Prime Minister Loses No-Confidence Vote
item.media:description: Prime Minister Stefan Lofven ruled out having any contacts with the anti-immigrant Sweden Democrats, saying, “time after time, their connections to racist and Nazi organizations have been exposed.”
item.description: Stefan Lofven’s defeat came after an election that stripped him of his majority and left the country with a hung Parliament.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
